passages.text: More Clues on the KSA

Meituan's and DHER's 2Q results shed more light on the Saudi food delivery market and Jahez's \(10\% / > 40\%\) GOV / EBITDA miss to consensus. Meituan: While 2Q revenue was softer, new Initiatives segment was ahead of the street/ JEFe estimates. We estimate that Keeta's KSA GMV could be almost on par with Jahez in 2Q. Furthermore, on the conference call, Meituan's management stated that Keeta is now a top- 2 player in the KSA and n1 in Hong Kong. Delivery Hero: HungerStation maintained \(>20\%\) order growth in 2Q, helped by "enhanced subscription offerings and vendor- funded promotions", the tools which we believe should also help Talabat to withstand Keeta.

Keeta's GMV could be on par with Jahez KSA in 2Q25. While Meituan's 2Q total revenue came in \(2\% /1.5\%\) below consensus/JEFe (due to the intensified competition in food delivery sector in China), new initiatives grew \(22.8\%\) Y/Y (vs consensus/JEFe of \(20.6\% /22.4\%\) Y/Y). We repeat the exercise from our MENA eFood initiation: New Initiatives commission revenue has expanded by RMB711m between 3Q24 and 2Q25; assuming \(75\%\) of the increase was driven by Keeta KSA and applying a \(c.18\%\) effective take rate (vs \(16\%\) for Jahez, i.e., assuming Keeta was charging restaurants in line with the market average and above Jahez), that could imply c.SAR1,535m GMV in 2Q25 (ex- VAT and delivery fees), equivalent to \(c.96\%\) of Jahez KSA GMV.

Hunger Station maintained \(>20\%\) Y/Y order growth in 2Q25, in line with 1Q25, and above \(14\%\) order growth reported by Jahez KSA. Delivery Hero notes "enhanced subscription offerings and vendor- funded promotions".
The Calls: "Long- Term" vs "Tactical" Investments
Meituan: Satisfying Diverse Needs of Different Segments with Emphasis on Efficiencies
DHER: 1H25 Results: First View

GMV, SAR m Assuming KSA contributed \(75\%\) to the incremental commission revenue of New Initiatives (vs 3Q24), and \(18\%\) take- rate, Keeta could generate c.SAR1,535m of GMV (ex- VAT) in 2Q25; \(96\%\) of Jahez KSA
Exhibit 2 - HungerStation order growth Y/Y \(>20\%\) in 2Q25 vs \(14\%\) Jahez
Source: Company reports, Jefferies. Note: using SAR/RMB of 1.93
Source: Company reports, Jefferies
Delivery Hero SEValuation: DCF- based, supported by multiples. Risks include aggressive competition and gig economy regulation.

Jahez International CoWe derive our SAR24.0 PT based on a DCF model. Our key assumptions include: (1) \(3.5\%\) PGR, (2) \(3.5\%\) terminal adjusted EBITDA / GOV margin, (3) \(0.5\%\) terminal capex/revenue. (4) \(12.7\%\) WACC (we apply an extra \(2.0\%\) risk premium to account for exacerbating competition). Key downside risks include: (1) further intensification of competition in particular with Keeta - in the KSA and potentially in Kuwait/Bahrain resulting in slower GOV growth and/or elevated customer incentives and marketing spend; (2) weaker than expected Saudi macro (largely reliant on oil prices) curbing consumer discretionary spend and pressurising AOV (correlation with GDP / capita is 0.9 globally) and delivery fees, (3) higher than expected cost inflation including cost of 3PL delivery, (4) operational risks. Key upside risks include: (1) lower than expected competitive pressure, including from bigger than expected positive impact from the upcoming regulation in the KSA resulting in faster than expected growth and profitability expansion; (2) better than expected macro in the region and in the KSA in particular, (3) lower than expected cost inflation boosting margins and FCF generation. (4) faster than expected business diversification allowing to materially boost revenue streams including from groceries and adtech.

MeituanWe have a Buy rating and PT of HKD139 based on P/E valuation. Risks include: (1) intensifying competitive landscape in food delivery, leading to aggressive subsidies and marketing efforts; (2) user experience is impaired on poor merchant service quality and unreliable user feedback; and (3) new initiatives incur significant losses and affect overall operating results.

TalabatWe derive our AED2.10 PT based on a DCF model. Our key assumptions include: (1) \(4.0\%\) PGR, (2) \(7.2\%\) terminal adjusted EBITDA / GMV margin, (3) \(0.3\%\) terminal capex/revenue. (4) \(12.5\%\) WACC (we apply an extra \(1.5\%\) risk premium to account for exacerbating competition). Key downside risks include: (1) intensification of competition in particular following potential expansion of Keeta across MENA resulting in slower GMV growth and/or elevated customer incentives and marketing spend; (2) weaker than expected macro curbing consumer discretionary spend and pressurising AOV (correlation with GDP / capita is 0.9 globally) and delivery fees, (3) higher than expected cost inflation including cost of 3PL delivery, (4) operational risks, (5) M&A and execution risks including related to integration of InstaShop, (6) risks for minorities investors posed by the ownership structure and decision- making controlled by DHER. Key upside risks include: (1) lower than expected competitive pressure resulting in faster than expected growth and profitability expansion; (2) better than expected macro in the region, (3) lower than expected cost inflation boosting margins and FCF generation, (4) bigger than expected synergies from InstaShop deal.

This analyst(s) may not be an associated person of Jefferies LLC, a FINRA member firm, and therefore may not be subject to the FINRA Rule 2241 and restrictions on communications with a subject company, public appearances and trading securities held by a research analyst.

As is the case with all Jefferies employees, the analyst(s) responsible for the coverage of the financial instruments discussed in this report receives compensation based in part on the overall performance of the firm, including investment banking income. We seek to update our research as appropriate, but various regulations may prevent us from doing so. Aside from certain industry reports published on a periodic basis, the large majority of reports are published at irregular intervals as appropriate in the analyst's judgement.
(Article 3(1)e) and Article 7 of MAR) Recommendation Published Recommendation Distributed

Buy - Describes securities that we expect to provide a total return (price appreciation plus yield) of \(15\%\) or more within a 12- month period. Hold - Describes securities that we expect to provide a total return (price appreciation plus yield) of plus \(15\%\) or minus \(10\%\) within a 12- month period. Underperform - Describes securities that we expect to provide a total return (price appreciation plus yield) of minus \(10\%\) or less within a 12- month period. The expected total return (price appreciation plus yield) for Buy rated securities with an average security price consistently below \(10\) is \(20\%\) or more within a 12- month period as these companies are typically more volatile than the overall stock market. For Hold rated securities with an average security price consistently below \(10\) , the expected total return (price appreciation plus yield) is plus or minus \(20\%\) within a 12- month period. For Underperform rated securities with an average security price consistently below \(10\) , the expected total return (price appreciation plus yield) is minus \(20\%\) or less within a 12- month period. NR - The investment rating and price target have been temporarily suspended. Such suspensions are in compliance with applicable regulations and/or Jefferies policies.
CS - Coverage Suspended. Jefferies has suspended coverage of this company.
NC - Not covered. Jefferies does not cover this company.

Restricted - Describes issuers where, in conjunction with Jefferies engagement in certain transactions, company policy or applicable securities regulations prohibit certain types of communications, including investment recommendations.
Monitor - Describes securities whose company fundamentals and financials are being monitored, and for which no financial projections or opinions on the investment merits of the company are provided.

Jefferies' methodology for assigning ratings may include the following: market capitalization, maturity, growth/value, volatility and expected total return over the next 12 months. The price targets are based on several methodologies, which may include, but are not restricted to, analyses of market risk, growth rate, revenue stream, discounted cash flow (DCF), EBITDA, EPS, cash flow (CF), free cash flow (FCF), EV/EBITDA, P/E, PE/growth, P/CF, P/FCF, premium (discount)/average group EV/EBITDA, premium (discount)/average group P/E, sum of the parts, net asset value, dividend returns, and return on equity (ROE) over the next 12 months.

Jefferies Franchise Picks include stock selections from among the best stock ideas from our equity analysts over a 12 month period. Stock selection is based on fundamental analysis and may take into account other factors such as analyst conviction, differentiated analysis, a favorable risk/reward ratio and investment themes that Jefferies analysts are recommending. Jefferies Franchise Picks will include only Buy rated stocks and the number can vary depending on analyst recommendations for inclusion. Stocks will be added as new opportunities arise and removed when the reason for inclusion changes, the stock has met its desired return, if it is no longer rated Buy and/or if it triggers a stop loss. Stocks having 120 day volatility in the bottom quartile of S&P stocks will continue to have a \(15\%\) stop loss, and the remainder will have a \(20\%\) stop. Franchise Picks are not intended to represent a recommended portfolio of stocks and is not sector based, but we may note where we believe a Pick falls within an investment style such as growth or value.

based on a currency conversion using an exchange rate as of the prior trading day (unless otherwise noted). Should there be fluctuations in the exchange rate after this date, that will affect the non- US target prices and should no longer be relied upon. In addition, investors in securities such as ADRs, whose values are affected by the currency of the underlying security, effectively assume currency risk.
